Got it
Youre asking how to mentally model the Knowledge Area architecture so you intuitively understand:

  • how files are grouped

  • which files matter first

  • how they trigger each other

Ill explain this in plain human language, using one main analogy, and briefly touch the others so it really clicks.

The BEST analogy for this system: A Skilled Salespersons Brain

This system is closer to a salespersons brain than a car.

Why?
Because:

  • It reacts, not just runs

  • It interprets signals

  • It decides what to say next

  • It doesnt execute everything at once

So lets model it that way.

Big Picture: How Knowledge Area Files Are Grouped

Think of the Knowledge Area as what the salesperson already knows before opening his mouth.

There are 4 natural groups (this is architecture reality, not invention):

1 IGNITION / SAFETY CORE

Am I allowed to speak? How should I behave?

This group decides IF and HOW the system is allowed to respond.

Files here:

  • RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md

What this group does (layman):

This is the salespersons self-control and rules.

Before he talks, his brain checks:

  • Am I allowed to answer this?

  • What rules must I obey?

  • What is my authority?

  • What should I never say?

Nothing else matters if this is wrong.

This group:

  • Loads everything else

  • Enforces boundaries

  • Prevents chaos

In your car analogy:
Ignition + dashboard + safety systems

In salesperson analogy:
Discipline, company policy, experience

2 QUALIFICATION / SITUATION AWARENESS

Who is this customer and whats going on?

This group interprets the customer.

Files here:

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md

  • (Later: silence / signal interpretation files)

What this group does:

The salesperson asks himself:

  • Is this a serious buyer?

  • Are they price shopping?

  • Are they confused?

  • Are they aggressive?

  • Are they silent?

This group:

  • Reads signals

  • Classifies intent

  • Decides how careful or aggressive to be

Car analogy:
Steering wheel & sensors

Sales analogy:
Reading body language, tone, hesitation

This group does NOT talk pricing yet
It only decides what mode the brain is in.

3 KNOWLEDGE CANONS (FACTS & TRUTH)

What do we actually sell?

This group is pure knowledge. No behavior. No strategy.

Files here:

  • SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY.md

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md

What this group does:

This is the salespersons memory:

  • How long services take

  • What options exist

  • What prices are possible

  • What combinations are valid

It does NOT decide:

  • how to negotiate

  • what tone to use

  • what strategy to apply

Car analogy:
Fuel + engine specifications

Sales analogy:
Product training

4 STRATEGY / RESPONSE SHAPING

How do I say it?

This group controls behavior, tone, and tactics.

Files here:

  • NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md

  • SILENCE_HANDLING.md

  • OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md

What this group does:

This is where the salesperson decides:

  • Should I push or wait?

  • Should I explain or ask?

  • Should I stay calm or firm?

  • Should I give a price or delay?

This group uses outputs from Groups 13.

Car analogy:
Acceleration, braking, indicators

Sales analogy:
Negotiation skills, communication style

Runtime Interaction (Simple Flow)

Heres what happens every single customer message:

  1. Runtime Core loads rules

    • What am I allowed to do?

  2. Qualification Engine reads the customer

    • Who am I dealing with?

  3. Knowledge Canons provide facts

    • What are the real options?

  4. Strategy Engines shape the response

    • How should I say this now?

Only then does the system speak.

So What MUST Be Perfect First?

The FIRST file to be correct and compliant is:

RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

Why?
Because:

  • It decides what loads

  • In what order

  • With what priority

  • And what gets ignored if conflict happens

If this is wrong:

  • Even perfect engines will misfire

  • Knowledge will clash

  • Behavior becomes inconsistent

SECOND priority:

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md

This enforces:

  • Authority

  • Boundaries

  • Safety rails

ONLY AFTER THAT:

  • Qualification

  • Then knowledge

  • Then negotiation finesse

Why the Car analogy is weaker (but still useful)

A car:

  • Runs everything simultaneously

  • Is mechanical

  • Has fixed behavior

Your system:

  • Thinks

  • Chooses

  • Reacts

  • Adjusts strategy mid-conversation

So the salesperson brain analogy is superior for this architecture.

Bottom line (plain English)

  • Think of files as mental layers, not documents

  • Some files decide if you can speak

  • Some understand the customer

  • Some store facts

  • Some decide how to talk

And you never perfect persuasion before discipline.

If you want, next step we can:

  • Map each existing file into this mental model

  • Or redraw the Knowledge Area as a one-page brain diagram

  • Or start freezing files in the correct priority order

ChatGPT said:

Below is a salesperson-brain view of each file: what it does, who calls it, what it reads, what it influences, and what happens in edge cases (unqualified, irrelevant, wrong service, etc.). Plain language, no fluff.

1) RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons mental checklist for how to run his brain.
It decides what knowledge to pull up first and which rules override others when things conflict.

Who calls it / when its used

  • Its effectively used at the start of every chat session (and conceptually before every response).

  • Think: before the salesperson speaks, his brain loads his company rules + product memory + playbooks in the right order.

What files it interacts with

It doesnt negotiate or qualify itself. It organizes and prioritizes other files.

It interacts with (by declaring load order / priority):

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md (core rules)

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (qualification logic)

  • SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY.md (truth about timelines)

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (truth about pricing)

  • NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md (discounting/ladder strategy)

  • SILENCE_HANDLING.md (what to do when customer disappears)

  • OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md (pushback handling)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (style rules)

The purpose (super simple)

If two files suggest different things, this file answers:

  • Which one wins?

  • Which one is consulted first?

  • Which one is allowed to change the final message?

If this file is wrong, the whole brain becomes inconsistent.

2) KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons core personality + company policy + safety boundaries.
This is the I will never do X, I must always do Y layer.

Who calls it / when its used

  • Loaded early (right after manifest).

  • Consulted all the time, because it sets guardrails for every reply.

What files it interacts with

It interacts with all engines because it constrains them:

  • Qualification: what questions are allowed, how to guide the conversation

  • Pricing & negotiation: authority boundaries (what discounts are allowed, what approvals are needed)

  • Service knowledge: prevents impossible promises

  • Tone: keeps language aligned to brand rules

  • Objections/friction: prevents arguing, keeps it professional

  • Silence: prevents spammy follow-ups, defines timing and style

Purpose in plain words

This file answers:

  • What am I allowed to promise?

  • What do I do when Im not sure?

  • When should I escalate / ask for more info?

  • What I should NOT say or do, even if the customer pushes.

If this is strong, your system doesnt leak weird behavior.

3) QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md

Youre thinking correctly: car model, year, driving habits = qualification inputs.

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons diagnosis brain.
It decides what the customer really needs and whether the customer is even in our world.

Who calls it / when its used

  • Triggered right after manifest/core rules, when:

    • customer asks something vague (how much? with no context)

    • customer asks for something outside scope (AC heat repair)

    • customer asks for something that might be the wrong service (painting when polishing could solve)

    • customer is a non-buyer (job request, marketing, supplier, random inquiries)

What files it interacts with

Qualification needs to route the conversation, so it interacts with:

  • SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY.md (to match needs to realistic timelines)

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (to avoid quoting blindly; quote ranges only if allowed)

  • Product/service canon (what services exist / dont exist)

  • NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md (only AFTER customer is qualified enough)

  • OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md (if the customer pushes back early)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (how politely to redirect when irrelevant)

Your scenarios (answered directly)

A) Customer is NOT relevant (AC repair, job request, marketing agency)

Qualification should do 3 things:

  1. Politely stop the wrong path

  2. Redirect to what Snash DOES do

  3. Ask one clean question to re-qualify (so it doesnt become a long lecture)

Example behavior (conceptually):

  • We dont do AC repair, but if your issue is heat / comfort / visibility, tint may help. Whats the car model/year and what exactly is the problem youre trying to solve?

B) Customer asks painting but polishing could solve

Qualification should:

  • Avoid contradicting the customer bluntly

  • Diagnose the outcome they want (scratches? oxidation? color fade?)

  • Offer the better matching service (polish) as an option

  • Only then price/timeline

So yes: this file should cover those routing cases (wrong service request correct service suggestion).

C) Customer is maybe qualified but unclear

Qualification should:

  • Ask minimum questions

  • Offer 23 likely service paths

  • Keep it short, not interrogative

If your QUALIFICATION_ENGINE is well designed, it becomes the traffic police that prevents waste.

4) NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons discount strategy + deal-shaping playbook.
Not emotions, not objections this is structured pricing moves.

Who calls it / when its used

Called only when:

  • Customer is qualified enough

  • Customer wants price OR pushes for discount

  • The system is allowed to negotiate (per core rules)

What files it interacts with

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (it must never invent numbers)

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md (authority limits)

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (uses qualification output to choose ladder step)

  • OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md (if discount request comes with attitude/friction)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (keep it human, not robotic)

What it does in plain language

It answers:

  • Do we give full price, bundle, add value, or reduce price?

  • If we reduce price, how much and under what conditions?

  • What is the next step if customer says no?

Think of it like:

  • Step 1: clarify scope (stop blind quotes)

  • Step 2: anchor value (what they get)

  • Step 3: offer package alternatives

  • Step 4: conditional concession (only if rules allow)

  • Step 5: close / book / deposit (if thats your flow)

5) SILENCE_HANDLING.md

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons follow-up instincts.
When the customer disappears, this prevents you from sounding desperate or spammy.

Who calls it / when its used

Triggered when:

  • Customer stops replying after quote

  • Customer says ok then disappears

  • Customer asks for details, then silence

  • Customer leaves you on read

What files it interacts with

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (follow-up tone)

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md (how many follow-ups allowed, boundaries)

  • NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md (if silence happened after a discount step, what next)

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (sometimes silence means they were never qualified; adjust approach)

What it does (plain)

It decides:

  • when to follow up

  • what to say (short nudge vs helpful info)

  • when to stop

It protects brand reputation.

6) OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md

Difference vs Negotiation Ladder (very important)

  • Negotiation Ladder = structured pricing / deal options

  • Objections & Friction = emotional + logical resistance handling

Simple comparison:

  • Ladder: Here are 3 package options and a conditional offer.

  • Objections: I hear you. Lets solve your concern: time / trust / quality / previous bad experience.

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons calm under pressure.
Handles:

  • suspicion (youre too expensive)

  • anger (last place ruined my car)

  • distrust (I dont trust garages)

  • time pressure (Im busy)

  • competition (X is cheaper)

Who calls it / when its used

Triggered when:

  • customer pushes back strongly

  • tone becomes rude

  • customer challenges credibility

  • price becomes a fight (not a negotiation)

What files it interacts with

  • KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md (dont argue / dont insult / boundaries)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (stay human, respectful)

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (facts to support value)

  • SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY.md (realistic expectations)

  • NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md (after objection is cooled, you can ladder again)

7) TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (Not created yet)

What it is in salesperson analogy

The salespersons style guide.
Same content, different delivery based on situation.

Who calls it / when its used

Always. Every output should pass through this lens:

  • friendly but not needy

  • confident but not arrogant

  • short, mobile-friendly

  • not ChatGPT-ish

What files it interacts with

Literally all of them:

  • Qualification questions phrasing

  • Negotiation wording

  • Objection responses

  • Silence follow-ups

  • Closing lines

What it does in plain words

It answers:

  • How do I sound like a real human at Snash?

  • How do I avoid sounding robotic?

  • How do I match the customer mood?

Where are product listing, warranties, etc. mentioned?

From your current architecture, these belong in Knowledge Canons (truth files), not engines.

Product / service listing

Usually lives in one place:

  • A service catalog / product master / canon file (if you already created it)
    OR embedded as a section inside:

  • SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY.md (services + timelines)

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (services + packages + pricing)

If you created product master modules and product canon earlier, that sounds like:

  • PRODUCT_CANON.md (or similar)

  • PRODUCT_MASTER_MODULES.md

If those exist and are meant for Knowledge Area uploads, they should be in the Knowledge upload list.

Warranties

Warranties should be in the same truth zone:

  • Best place: a dedicated section inside the product canon (or inside SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY if thats your truth file)

Reason: warranty is not strategy; its policy/fact.

Where are the tone engines?

Right now, tone is spread across behavior files, but the clean way is:

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md = the single source of how we sound

  • Other engines reference it.

So yes: tone engine is basically the playbook that everything obeys.

How is closing done?

Closing is usually a combination of:

  1. Qualification output (are they ready to book?)

  2. Negotiation ladder step (final offer or package)

  3. Tone playbook (confident CTA)

  4. Core bundle rules (dont overpromise; keep it simple)

A closing typically includes:

  • a clear next step: share car model/year + preferred date

  • or send location / book slot / confirm package

  • plus a soft confirmation: Want Option A or B?

Where should closing rules live?

  • If its general how to end messages TONE_PLAYBOOK.md

  • If its step-based (after which ladder step we close) NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md

Quick summary: who interacts with who (one-liner map)

  • Manifest loads + orders everything

  • Core bundle constrains everything

  • Qualification decides the track (relevant, irrelevant, which service)

  • Canon files provide facts (services, timelines, prices, warranty)

  • Negotiation ladder chooses deal structure

  • Objections/friction cools resistance

  • Silence handles follow-up timing + wording

  • Tone playbook makes everything sound human + consistent

ChatGPT said:

Yes your understanding is directionally correct, and this is an important clarification.
Let me lock this mentally for you in very simple salesperson language, step-by-step, without drifting into theory.

Short answer (clear & direct)

YES.
The correct flow is:

Qualification Pricing / Option Framing Negotiation (only if needed)

Negotiation is NOT where pricing starts.
Negotiation is what happens after a sensible price + options have already been presented.

The clean mental model (salesperson brain)

The salesperson does NOT think like:

Let me negotiate.

He thinks like:

Let me understand you give you the right options anchor the value only negotiate if you resist.

Thats exactly what you described.

1 After QUALIFICATION, what comes next?

After QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md decides:

  • This customer is relevant

  • What car they have

  • What problem theyre trying to solve

  • How informed / serious they are

The brain moves to PRICING + OPTION FRAMING, NOT negotiation yet.

2 Is there a separate Pricing Engine?

Technically: YES, conceptually

File-wise: NO new engine is required (yet)

Right now, pricing logic lives across two knowledge layers:

A) PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (truth layer)

This contains:

  • Base prices

  • Car segment pricing (sedan, SUV, luxury, etc.)

  • Service-specific prices (PPF, ceramic, polish, tint)

  • Any known constraints

This file never persuades.
It just knows the numbers.

B) QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (decision layer)

This is the key insight:

Qualification does NOT stop at asking questions.

It also:

  • Chooses which price range to surface

  • Chooses which service options to mention

  • Decides how direct or cautious pricing should be

So yes pricing selection is driven by qualification output.

Example (your PPF on old car scenario)

Customer:

I want PPF on my 8-year-old car.

What happens internally:

Step 1 Qualification Engine:

  • Car age: old

  • Service requested: PPF

  • Risk: poor PPF outcome if paint condition is bad

  • Customer intent: protection / appearance (likely, not confirmed)

Qualification decides:

  • This is allowed but risky

  • Needs inspection

  • Alternative services may be better (polish / ceramic)

Step 2 Pricing & Option Framing (still NOT negotiation):

The system:

  • Acknowledges PPF exists (dont say no)

  • Avoids final pricing

  • Frames inspection + alternatives

Example behavior:

Yes, we do PPF. For older cars, we usually inspect the paint first because polishing or ceramic may give better results at a lower cost. Once we see the condition, well recommend the best option.

This is NOT negotiation.
This is guided pricing + option steering.

3 Where does anchoring price happen?

Anchoring happens BEFORE negotiation.

Anchoring is:

  • Giving a realistic price range

  • Explaining value

  • Presenting options (good / better / best)

  • Setting expectations

Anchoring is done by:

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (decides what to anchor)

  • PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (provides numbers)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (how its said)

Example (anchoring, not negotiating):

For your car type, polishing usually starts from X, ceramic from Y, and full PPF is higher depending on condition. Thats why we inspect first.

No discount.
No concession.
No ladder movement.

4 So when does NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md actually activate?

Only when ONE of these happens:

  • Customer pushes back on price

  • Customer compares competitors

  • Customer asks for discount

  • Customer says too expensive

  • Customer wants something extra for same price

Thats when the salesperson thinks:

Okay, now were negotiating.

5 What is the TRUE purpose of NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md?

In layman terms:

It prevents random discounting and emotional decisions.

It answers:

  • If I move, how much can I move?

  • Should I add value instead of cutting price?

  • Whats my next step if they say no again?

It does NOT:

  • Decide base price

  • Decide which service fits

  • Educate customer on options

Those already happened earlier.

6 Where does customer demography fit? (Arab / expat / Saudi etc.)

Important clarification:

Demography should:

  • Influence tone and explanation depth

  • Influence examples and reassurance

  • Possibly influence service emphasis

But it should NOT change prices directly unless:

  • Your PRICE_REPOSITORY explicitly allows it (e.g. segment-based pricing)

So demography feeds into:

  • QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md (communication strategy)

  • TONE_PLAYBOOK.md (how formal / friendly / brief)

  • OBJECTIONS_HANDLING.md (trust patterns)

Not raw pricing numbers (unless policy allows).

7 So who automatically picks the right path?

This is the chain:

  1. RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

    • Loads everything, enforces order

  2. KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md

    • Sets rules: inspect before risky promises, no blind PPF guarantees, etc.

  3. QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md

    • Interprets customer

    • Routes to:

      • direct pricing

      • inspection-first

      • alternative service suggestion

      • exit / redirect

  4. PRICE_REPOSITORY.md

    • Supplies correct numbers / ranges

  5. NEGOTIATION_LADDER_ENGINE.md

    • Only activates if resistance appears

Final confirmation (important)

Yes pricing & option framing come before negotiation
Yes qualification decides what pricing path is even allowed
Yes negotiation is only for resistance, not education
Yes old-car / wrong-service scenarios are handled in Qualification, not negotiation

Youre thinking about this exactly like a senior salesperson, not a chatbot.

  • Decide whether pricing logic stays inside Qualification or deserves a separate Pricing Engine file

  • Or freeze this flow and move to file-by-file freeze starting with RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

2 WHERE SILENCE_HANDLING.md FITS (CLEARLY)

Silence is not a separate main path it is a state that can happen in two places:

Silence Scenario A After pricing (most common)

Customer:

  • reads the price

  • doesnt reply

SILENCE_HANDLING.md activates

  • decides when to follow up

  • decides what kind of follow-up

  • checks CORE rules (dont spam)

  • uses TONE_PLAYBOOK for wording

Silence Scenario B After negotiation step

Customer:

  • pushed back

  • you offered a ladder step

  • then disappears

SILENCE module:

  • checks what ladder step was last used

  • decides whether to:

    • remind value

    • offer alternative

    • stop following up

So silence handling is horizontal, not vertical.

  3. If two people in the company tell me different things, whose instruction wins?

What it really controls

    • qualification second

    • facts third

    • repositories override improvisation

    • negotiation cannot break authority limits

2) If assistant uploads IG/FB profile homepage screenshot, can I infer behavior and use it later?

  • language preference

  • business vs individual vibes

  • whether it looks like a reseller/agency

  • brand tone expectations (formal vs casual)

  • potential high-value customer cues (luxury content, car-focused content)

BUT:

  • Its not always reliable.

  • We should treat it as soft signals, not facts.

  • And we should never make assumptions that could sound creepy or invasive.

How we handle it cleanly:

  • Use it internally as soft persona hints

  • Only influence:

    • tone suggestions

    • how much we explain

    • how direct we are

  • Do not mention profile analysis to the customer.

This fits your future extensibility idea and does not require new files right now.

Recommended canonical title format (Cross-platform, underscore, searchable)

Primary rule (always)

Use this as the SNASHGPT window title:

text
<CHANNEL>_<HANDLE>_<PHONEorNA>_<CARorNA>_<YEARorNA>_<DATEFIRST>

Field rules (simple)

  • CHANNEL: IG / FB / WA / MB (Meta Business unknown IG/FB) / UNK

  • HANDLE: Instagram @handle OR FB display name (normalized, no spaces: use - or remove spaces)

  • PHONEorNA: last 4 or full if you prefer. If missing: NA

  • CARorNA: model (short code if needed), else NA

  • YEARorNA: else NA

  • DATEFIRST: first contact date in YYYYMMDD

Examples

text
IG_mohd-ali_NA_NA_NA_20260105
MB_ahmed-saleh_9733XXX123_Camry_2022_20260105
WA_9733XXX123_9733XXX123_Patrol_2020_20260105
FB_Sara-Ali_NA_NA_NA_20260105

Why this is the best for your ops (practical reasons)

  • Cross-platform search: you can search the same string in Meta, WhatsApp saved contacts, Zoho, and SNASHGPT.

  • Stable identity first: channel + handle/phone anchors the person even before car details exist.

  • No duplicates: phone becomes the strongest dedupe key when available.

  • Append-friendly: you can update CAR/YEAR later without changing the core identity.

Update rule (prevents duplicate windows)

When new info arrives (car, year, phone), you update the same title, not create a new page.

Dedupe trigger (simple)

# RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md

## PHASE 0  INTAKE & CONTROL RULES

### Identity & Context Integrity
- One customer per runtime window.
- Mixed or conflicting identities must halt progression.
- Assistants may paste any number of messages; order matters, not count.
- Latest messages define the active state.

### Duplicate Detection
- Matching phone number = same customer.
- Strong name/intent similarity triggers assistant confirmation for merge.
- No automatic merging is permitted.

### Title Enforcement (Canonical)
SNASHGPT window title format:
<PRIMARY_ID>_<CHANNEL>_<STAGE>

PRIMARY_ID:
- Customer name OR WhatsApp number.

CHANNEL:
- IG / FB / WA / MB

STAGE:
- HOT / WARM / COLD / FOLLOWUP / LOST

Titles may be updated as clarity improves.
New windows must not be created for the same customer.

---

### Fast-Path Handover
If a customer provides a phone number in the first message and requests a call:
- Acknowledge receipt.
- Generate or update title.
- Prepare handover note.
- Stop chat-side selling immediately.

---

### Non-Customer-Facing Orientation
Phase 0 may output internal guidance in English only:
- Customer stage
- Customer type
- Current conversation phase
- Warnings (do not quote, inspection needed, possible duplicate)

No customer-facing persuasion occurs in Phase 0.

---

### Anti-Repetition Guard
- Detect repeated explanations, pricing, or apologies.
- Inform assistant only.
- Must not override downstream engines.

---

## DECLARATIONS
The following modules exist and apply globally, but do not execute in Phase 0:
- Qualification Engine
- Pricing Repository
- Negotiation Ladder Engine
- Silence Handling
- Tone Playbook
- Sales Handover Rules

Execution is permitted only after Phase 0 completion.

md
# KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md
Version: 1.0
Scope: Global Runtime Guardrails + Phase 0 Controls
Status: LOCK CANDIDATE

---

## PURPOSE
This file defines the non-negotiable runtime guardrails that apply across all phases.
It controls:
- What the assistant is allowed to do (authority boundaries)
- Output discipline (internal vs customer-facing)
- Debug trace tags (source visibility for admin)
- Assistant flag protocol (#FLAG_*)
- Duplicate customer handling + handover safety
- Anti-repetition guardrails

---

## GOLDEN RULES (ALWAYS ON)
1) Never proceed if customer identity is mixed or conflicting.
2) Never auto-merge customers; require assistant confirmation.
3) Never invent facts, prices, warranties, timelines, or policies.
4) Always separate internal guidance from customer-facing messages.
5) Always avoid repeating the same explanation/price/apology if already sent (anti-repetition).
6) Always treat the latest pasted messages as the active state, unless identity conflict is detected.

---

## OUTPUT DISCIPLINE (STRICT)
### A) Internal Output (for assistants/admin only)
- English only.
- Must be short, direct, and action-oriented.
- Must include a SOURCE TRACE line (see Trace Tags).

### B) Customer-Facing Output
- Must follow the Language Output Discipline Guard rules:
  - Translation-first for Arabic inputs
  - Suggested reply must be provided in BOTH English and Arabic
  - Arabic reply must be in an easy-to-copy block

NOTE: This file does not repeat the full language guard text.
It enforces that the guard exists and must be followed.

---

## INTERNAL RESPONSE FORMAT (STANDARD)
When assistants paste chats/screenshots, internal output should use this structure:

1) TRANSLATION (if Arabic present)  English translation of latest messages
2) CONTEXT SNAPSHOT  what happened in the last visible sequence (13 bullets)
3) STAGE TAG  HOT / WARM / COLD / FOLLOWUP / LOST
4) CUSTOMER TYPE TAGS (best-effort)  e.g., price-sensitive, confused, high-intent, silent-risk, frustrated
5) NEXT STEP  one clear action for the assistant
6) WARNINGS  only if needed (do not quote yet, possible duplicate, inspection needed, etc.)
7) SOURCE TRACE  required line showing which files influenced the guidance

---

## TRACE TAGS (SOURCE TRACE)  REQUIRED
Internal messages must include:
SOURCE TRACE: <FILE_A> > <FILE_B> > <FILE_C>

Allowed file names in trace:
- RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md
- KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md
- CUSTOMER_CHAT_INTAKE_RULES.md (if referenced)
- CHAT_CONTEXT_RESUME_RULE.md (if referenced)
- LANGUAGE_OUTPUT_DISCIPLINE_GUARD.md (if referenced)
- QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md
- PRICE_REPOSITORY.md
- SERVICE_DELIVERY_REFERENCE_REPOSITORY.md
- PRODUCT_KNOWLEDGE_CANON.md
- NEGOTIATION_PRICE_LADDER_ENGINE.md
- OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md
- SILENCE_HANDLING.md
- TONE_PLAYBOOK.md
- SALES_HANDOVER_RULE.md

Trace is internal-only. Never show trace to customers.

---

## ADMIN FLAG PROTOCOL (#FLAG_*)  INTERNAL ONLY
Assistants can append one flag line anywhere in their internal prompt:
- #FLAG_TRACE      (response source unclear / wrong file behavior)
- #FLAG_TONE       (tone mismatch / sounds robotic / too harsh)
- #FLAG_PRICE      (pricing conflict / outdated pricing / wrong package)
- #FLAG_DUPLICATE  (same customer might exist in another window)
- #FLAG_HANDOVER   (handover confusion / wrong timing)
- #FLAG_SILENCE    (silence recovery needed / timing gap concern)

When a #FLAG_* is present, the assistant must receive:
- A short explanation of what likely went wrong
- A SOURCE TRACE line
- A recommendation of which file section to review/update

No automated merging or silent corrections are permitted.

---

## DUPLICATE CUSTOMER HANDLING (MULTI-CHANNEL)
- If phone number matches: treat as same customer.
- If strong similarity (name + car + intent): prompt assistant to confirm merge.
- Never auto-merge two SNASHGPT windows.
- If a merge is confirmed, the assistant must:
  - Choose ONE primary window
  - Paste the missing channel messages into that window in chronological order (best-effort)
  - Update the title to the simple canonical format

---

## TITLE ENFORCEMENT (CANONICAL)
SNASHGPT window title must be:
<PRIMARY_ID>_<CHANNEL>_<STAGE>

PRIMARY_ID:
- Customer name OR WhatsApp number (whichever is clearer)

CHANNEL:
- IG / FB / WA / MB

STAGE:
- HOT / WARM / COLD / FOLLOWUP / LOST

Optional fields (car/year) may be used by humans in contacts/CRM, but are not required in the SNASHGPT title.
Titles may be updated; do not create new windows for the same customer.

---

## HANDOVER AUTHORITY (FAST-PATH RULE)
If the customer provides a phone number and requests a call:
- Acknowledge the request.
- Prepare a handover note (internal).
- Stop chat-side selling immediately.
- Sales team continues on WhatsApp/call using the same title reference.

---

## HANDOVER NOTE (MINIMUM FIELDS)  INTERNAL
When handing over to sales, include:
- Title (canonical)
- Phone number
- Channel source (IG/FB/MB/WA)
- Car model/year (if known)
- Service intent (what they asked for)
- Current stage (HOT/WARM/etc.)
- Next recommended step (call script angle / inspection suggestion / booking ask)

---

## ANTI-REPETITION GUARD (GLOBAL)
- If a price/explanation/apology was already provided in the visible context,
  do not repeat it verbatim.
- Instead:
  - summarize in one line, or
  - move to next step, or
  - ask a clarifying question.

Anti-repetition is advisory and must not block correct progression.

---

## PHASE BOUNDARY ENFORCEMENT (SUMMARY)
- Phase 0: intake, identity, title, flags, trace, handover safety
- Phase 1+: qualification/pricing/negotiation/silence/tone occur only after Phase 0 integrity is satisfied

---

# KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md

Version: 1.0  
Scope: Runtime Knowledge Guardrails (Pre-Execution)  
Phase: 0  Intake & Control  
Status: LOCK CANDIDATE  

---

## PURPOSE

This document defines the **non-negotiable runtime guardrails** that govern
how knowledge, context, pricing references, and behavioral signals are handled
before any execution engine is allowed to run.

This file does **not** execute logic.  
It **gates**, **classifies**, and **protects** runtime flow integrity.

---

## POSITION IN ARCHITECTURE

Execution Order:

1. RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md  
2. KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md   (this file)
3. Qualification Engine  
4. Knowledge / Pricing / Timeline Repositories  
5. Persuasion & Negotiation Engines  

No engine may bypass Phase 0.

---

## CORE PRINCIPLES

### 1. Phase Authority
- Phase 0 has absolute authority to **halt**, **gate**, or **delay** execution.
- No downstream engine may override Phase 0 decisions.

---

### 2. Identity & Context Integrity

- One customer per runtime window.
- Mixed, conflicting, or ambiguous identities halt progression.
- Assistants may paste any number of messages; **sequence matters, not volume**.
- The **latest valid message defines active state** unless explicitly overridden.

---

### 3. Duplicate & Continuity Handling

- Matching phone number = same customer.
- Strong name / intent similarity triggers **assistant confirmation**, not auto-merge.
- No automatic customer merging is permitted at runtime.

---

### 4. Anti-Repetition & Learning Protection

- Runtime behavior **must never change based on a single incident**.
- Corrections, one-off clarifications, or isolated objections are **not learnings**.
- Learning eligibility requires **repeated patterns across multiple customers**.
- Pattern recognition is observational, not automatic.

---

### 5. Safety Dominance (Non-Engine)

Safety is enforced as a **Phase 0 authority**, not as a runtime engine.

- Unknown, unsafe, or contradictory inputs halt execution.
- Safety overrides all engines, prices, and persuasion logic.
- Safety logic is referenced, not duplicated, in downstream systems.

---

### 6. Pricing Guardrails (Pre-Execution)

- Pricing output must **never open** with:
  Original price is X, discounted price is Y.
- Discount framing is prohibited at initial pricing disclosure.
- Discounts may only be surfaced **after pricing pressure is classified**.
- Discount logic is controlled by downstream pricing systems, not Phase 0.

---

### 7. Discount Control Boundary

- Phase 0 may **classify pricing pressure signals**.
- Phase 0 does **not** authorize, compute, or suggest discounts.
- All discount execution remains outside this bundle.

---

### 8. Silence & Negotiation Signals (Classification Only)

- Silence risk may be **flagged**, never resolved, in Phase 0.
- No silence recovery, persuasion, or follow-up logic executes here.
- Negotiation pressure is observed via:
  - Repeated price probing
  - Hesitation loops
  - Clarification cycling

---

### 9. Visual Usage Safety (High-Level)

- Visual assets may be used at **any phase**, subject to safety and clarity checks.
- Visuals are a **delivery format**, not a persuasion trigger by default.
- Visual strategy and sequencing are handled downstream.

---

### 10. Shadow Learning Boundary

- Shadow observations may be logged externally.
- Phase 0 does **not** adapt behavior based on shadow outcomes.
- Human review is required before doctrine updates.

---

## NON-GOALS (Explicit)

This file does NOT:
- Execute qualification logic
- Perform pricing calculations
- Apply discounts
- Recover silence
- Negotiate objections
- Learn or mutate behavior automatically

---

## LOCK RULE

Once locked:
- Any change requires:
  - Architecture review
  - Manifest compatibility check
  - Version increment

End of file.

  • Did not inflate file count

  • Did not leak shadow logic into runtime

  • Did not contradict the Manifest

  2. Or run a Manifest Core Bundle cross-check

  3. Or create the human-readable explainer version you mentioned earlier

# KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md
Version: 1.0
Scope: Runtime Knowledge Guardrails (Pre-Execution)
Phase: 0  Intake & Control
Status: LOCK CANDIDATE

---

## PURPOSE

This document defines the **non-negotiable runtime guardrails** that govern how context, identity, repositories, and signals are handled **before any engine is allowed to run**.

This file does **not** execute qualification, pricing, negotiation, silence recovery, or persuasion.
It **gates, classifies, and protects** runtime flow integrity.

---

## POSITION IN ARCHITECTURE (EXECUTION ORDER)

1) RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md
2) KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md   (this file)
3) Qualification Engine
4) Knowledge / Pricing / Timeline Repositories
5) Negotiation / Objections / Silence / Tone / Visual usage modules

Rule: **No engine may bypass Phase 0.**

---

## GOLDEN RULES (ALWAYS ON)

1) **One customer per runtime window.**
2) If identity is mixed / conflicting / ambiguous  **halt progression** and request clarification.
3) **Never invent facts** (prices, warranty terms, timelines, policies, offers).
4) Always separate **internal guidance** from **customer-facing copy**.
5) Anti-repetition: if the same explanation/price/apology was already provided in the visible context  **do not repeat verbatim**; summarize or move forward.
6) Latest valid message defines active state **unless identity conflict exists**.

(Safety dominance: if anything is uncertain/unsafe  safety wins and output is softened/escalated.)

Reference basis: safety dominance + no invention principles. (See legacy safety sources.)
- 00_SAFETY_OVERRIDE_ENGINE_v2.0 (legacy)
- 00_SafetyUnknownHandling_v0.1 (legacy)

---

## OUTPUT DISCIPLINE (STRICT SEPARATION)

### A) Internal Output (admin / operator / assistant thinking)
- English only.
- Short, direct, action-oriented.
- Must include a SOURCE TRACE line (see Trace Tags).
- Must not include Arabic customer copy mixed inside internal notes.

### B) Customer-Facing Output (what the human will send)
- Must follow the Language Output Discipline Guard (if that file is in the runtime set).
- If bilingual output is required by your operating standard:
  - Provide EN + AR clearly separated.
- Never expose internal trace tags or flags to customers.

---

## INTERNAL RESPONSE FORMAT (STANDARD)

When chats/screenshots are pasted, internal output should follow:

1) TRANSLATION (if Arabic present)  English translation of latest messages
2) CONTEXT SNAPSHOT  what happened in the last visible sequence (13 bullets)
3) PHASE TAG  HOT / WARM / COLD / FOLLOWUP / LOST
4) SIGNAL TAGS (best-effort)  price-pressure, confusion, silent-risk, high-intent, frustrated, etc.
5) NEXT STEP  one clear action
6) WARNINGS  only if needed (duplicate risk, identity conflict, safety risk, etc.)
7) SOURCE TRACE  required line showing which files influenced guidance

---

## TRACE TAGS (SOURCE TRACE)  REQUIRED

Internal messages must include:

SOURCE TRACE: <FILE_A> > <FILE_B> > <FILE_C>

Allowed file names in trace (only those that exist in your runtime freeze / manifest):
- RUNTIME_LOAD_MANIFEST.md
- KNOWLEDGE__RUNTIME_CORE_BUNDLE.md
- CUSTOMER_CHAT_INTAKE_RULES.md (if included)
- CHAT_CONTEXT_RESUME_RULE_v1.0.txt (if included)
- FILE  LANGUAGE_OUTPUT_DISCIPLINE_GUARD_v1.0.txt (if included)
- QUALIFICATION_ENGINE.md
- PRICE_REPOSITORY.md (or your current pricing repository name)
- SERVICE_TIMELINE_REPOSITORY_v1.0.md
- PRODUCT_KNOWLEDGE_CANON.md
- NEGOTIATION_PRICE_LADDER_ENGINE.md
- OBJECTIONS_AND_FRICTION_HANDLING.md
- SILENCE_HANDLING.md
- TONE_PLAYBOOK.md
- FILE 7  SALES_HANDOVER_RULE_v1_LOCKED.txt (handover)

Rule: Trace is internal-only. Never show trace to customers.

---

## ADMIN FLAG PROTOCOL (#FLAG_*)  INTERNAL ONLY

Assistants/operators may append one flag line anywhere in internal prompts:

- #FLAG_TRACE        (response source unclear / wrong file behavior)
- #FLAG_TONE         (tone mismatch / sounds robotic / too harsh)
- #FLAG_IDENTITY     (identity conflict / possible duplicate customer/window)
- #FLAG_PRICING      (price confusion / discount pressure / anchor risk)
- #FLAG_SILENCE      (silence risk / followup timing concern)
- #FLAG_SAFETY       (unsafe / illegal / warranty risk / overpromise risk)
- #FLAG_CONFLICT     (rule overlap detected; requires conflict check)

When a #FLAG_* is present, the assistant must return:
- A short explanation of what likely went wrong
- A SOURCE TRACE line
- A recommendation of which file section to review/update
- No silent corrections and no auto-merging.

---

## DUPLICATE CUSTOMER + CONTINUITY HANDLING (MULTI-CHANNEL)

- Matching phone number  treat as same customer (for humans), but do not auto-merge runtime windows.
- Strong similarity (name + car + intent)  prompt operator confirmation; do not assume merge.
- No automatic customer merging is permitted at runtime.

If a merge is confirmed by operator:
- Choose one primary window
- Paste missing channel messages into that window in chronological order (best-effort)
- Keep title canonical (see next section)

---

## TITLE ENFORCEMENT (CANONICAL)

SNASHGPT window title must be:

PRIMARY_ID-<CHANNEL>-<STAGE>

PRIMARY_ID:
- Customer name OR WhatsApp number (whichever is clearer)

CHANNEL:
- IG / FB / WA / MB

STAGE:
- HOT / WARM / COLD / FOLLOWUP / LOST

Rule:
- Titles may be updated.
- Do not create new windows for the same customer unless identity conflict requires separation.

---

## HANDOVER AUTHORITY (FAST-PATH RULE)

If the customer provides a phone number and requests a call:
- Acknowledge the request
- Prepare a handover note (internal)
- Stop chat-side selling immediately
- Sales team continues on WhatsApp/call using the same title reference

Minimum fields in handover note (internal):
- Title (canonical)
- Phone number
- Channel source (IG/FB/MB/WA)
- Car model/year (if known)
- Service intent (what they asked for)
- Objections raised
- Current stage (HOT/WARM/etc.)
- Next recommended step (call script angle / inspection suggestion / booking ask)

(Reference: Sales handover rule file, if present.)

---

## ANTI-REPETITION GUARD (GLOBAL)

If a price / explanation / apology was already provided in visible context:
- Do not repeat it verbatim.
Instead:
- summarize in one line, OR
- move to the next step, OR
- ask one clarifying question.

Anti-repetition is advisory and must not block correct progression.

---

## SAFETY DOMINANCE (PHASE 0 AUTHORITY, NOT A NEW ENGINE)

Safety is enforced as a Phase 0 authority layer.

- Unknown, unsafe, illegal, or contradictory inputs  halt or soften output.
- Safety overrides qualification, pricing, negotiation, visual usage, and persuasion.
- Do not promise exact outcomes, exact warranty terms, exact timelines, refunds, or compensation.
- Do not invent offers/discounts.

(Aligned with legacy safety principles: if unsure  clarify instead of guessing, never mention non-existent discounts.)

---

## PRICING GUARDRAILS (PRE-EXECUTION ONLY)

Phase 0 may classify pricing pressure signals, but does not execute pricing logic.

Hard rules:
- Pricing output must **never open** with:
  Original price is X, discounted price is Y.
- Do not frame discounts at initial disclosure.
- Do not invent bundles, free items, or today only urgency.
- If the customer asks for discount early:
  - classify it as price-pressure
  - route to downstream pricing/negotiation logic OR offer-check via human

---

## DISCOUNT CONTROL BOUNDARY (CONTROLLED, NOT INVENTED)

Phase 0 rules:
- Phase 0 may **detect** discount pressure.
- Phase 0 must **not** authorize, calculate, or propose discounts.
- If an offer may exist, allowed phrasing is offer-check only:
  I can ask the team if any valid offer applies to your car.

All discount execution remains outside this bundle (pricing/negotiation layer + human policy).

(Reason: avoids conflict with safety rules against non-existent discounts and compensation.)

---

## SILENCE + NEGOTIATION SIGNALS (CLASSIFICATION ONLY)

Phase 0 may flag:
- Silence risk (stalling, last-message drop, hesitation loops)
- Negotiation pressure signals:
  - repeated price probing
  - clarification cycling
  - whats best price loops

But Phase 0 must NOT:
- run silence recovery sequences
- run persuasion scripts
- negotiate objections
- apply value reframes

Those belong to downstream engines/modules.

---

## VISUAL USAGE SAFETY (HIGH-LEVEL, FLEXIBLE)

Visuals may be used at **any phase**, subject to safety + clarity checks.

Rules:
- Visuals are a delivery format, not a persuasion trigger by default.
- Visual strategy/sequencing is handled downstream (not in Phase 0).
- Phase 0 only enforces: no misleading claims, no unsafe promises, no illegal guidance.

(This keeps visuals flexible for future product comparison visuals without locking you into one phase.)

---

## PROGRESSING WHILE NARROWING (FLOW DISCIPLINE)

Rule:
- We move forward, not sideways.
- Explicit intent narrows focus but does not erase adjacent viable options.
- Avoid looping qualification questions; ask the minimum to proceed.

(Aligned with shadow contract: explicit intent narrows focus, never eliminates alternatives.)

---

## SHADOW LEARNING BOUNDARY (NO AUTO-MUTATION)

Shadow observations may be logged externally.
Runtime behavior must not change based on a single incident.

Learning eligibility:
- Requires repeated patterns across multiple customers/chats.
- Human review required before doctrine updates.
- Patching must follow conflict-check discipline (amend existing blocks; dont duplicate).

---

## BACKEND PATTERN VISIBILITY (HIGH-LEVEL, LAYMAN)

How you see patterns without automation:
- You will see repeated #FLAG_* lines across chats.
- You will see repeated customer reactions (same confusion, same objection, same drop-off).
- Weekly: you scan the log set and count repeats.
- If it repeats enough  it becomes a lock candidate and you patch the correct file.

Admin effort (minimal practical loop):
1) Keep a simple Shadow Learnings Log file (date + issue + flag).
2) Once per week: search that file for repeated keywords/flags.
3) Only then: patch doctrine.

No automation is required for v1.0. (Automation can be added later.)

---

## DO-NOT-LOG / PRIVACY (PHASE 0 CONSTRAINT)

- Do not store sensitive personal data in doctrine text.
- Do not behave as if you remember past private details unless operator pasted them into the current chat.
- Only request phone number through the correct capture/handover rules.

(Aligned with safety privacy principles.)

---

## NON-GOALS (EXPLICIT)

This file does NOT:
- Execute qualification logic
- Perform pricing calculations
- Apply discounts
- Recover silence
- Negotiate objections
- Learn or mutate behavior automatically

---

## LOCK RULE

Once locked:
- Any change requires:
  - Architecture review
  - Manifest compatibility check
  - Version increment
  - Conflict check (amend existing blocks; do not duplicate)

End of file.
